title: What to know about Oklahoma's new 6-week abortion ban law
description: Oklahoma implemented a six-week abortion ban. Here's everything to know about the new law that closely copies abortion restrictions imposed in Texas.

text: What to know about Oklahoma's new 6-week abortion ban lawNews Sports Life Opinion Business Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals  NEWSWhat we know, and what we don't, about Oklahoma's 6-week abortion banDana Branham Carmen FormanOklahomanAbortion access was drastically limited in Oklahoma this week when Gov. Kevin Stitt signed a bill that bans most abortions after roughly the sixth week of pregnancy.Restrictions may get even tighter soon, as the U.S. Supreme Court has signaled it’s willing to overturn Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision that upheld the right to abortion. Related:What banning abortion means for Oklahoma doctors and pregnant patientsIf the court reverses Roe, abortion will immediately become outlawed in nearly all instances across Oklahoma because of a “trigger law” Stitt signed in 2021.But for now, abortions are still legal in Oklahoma if they occur within the first six weeks of pregnancy, though that’s before many women know they’re pregnant. State data from 2017 through 2020 shows that the majority of abortions recorded in Oklahoma happen after six weeks’ gestation. After the implementation of Senate Bill 1503, women further along in their pregnancies may be pushed out of state to Kansas, New Mexico or Colorado to get an abortion. Here’s what we know — and what we don’t — about how Oklahoma’s restrictive new abortion law works and who it affects. SB 1503 took effect immediately Tuesday.What changed compared to Oklahoma’s previous laws on abortion?The state previously prohibited most abortions after 20 weeks post-fertilization. Viability, or when a fetus can survive outside the womb, is typically 24 weeks or later.  Under the new law, abortion will effectively be banned after a “fetal heartbeat” is detected. Although that term is a misnomer, abortion clinics will stop providing the procedure after about the sixth week of pregnancy. Related:'It's horrible.' Uncertainty looms as Oklahoma clinic braces for Texas-style abortion banAbortion providers and reproductive rights groups have asked the Oklahoma Supreme Court to block the new law. The court declined to issue a temporary injunction that would have immediately halted implementation of SB 1503, but the court is still considering the broader legal challenge. Despite lawsuits, Texas’ Senate Bill 8, which SB 1503 copies, is still in place after taking effect in September. That could be a sign that challenging Oklahoma’s civil enforcement law could be an uphill fight. If the U.S. Supreme Court reverses Roe and allows states to set abortion policy, legal challenges against SB 1503 may become moot. Who can sue and be sued under Oklahoma's abortion law?Anyone who “knowingly engages” in conduct that “aids or abets” a woman seeking an abortion after a “fetal heartbeat” is detected could face a civil lawsuit. The law includes little detail about what counts as aiding or abetting. But the law is written in such a way that someone could be sued even if they don’t realize they’re breaking the law by helping a woman. Women seeking an abortion could not be sued. In what appears to be protections for taxi, Uber and Lyft drivers, the law stipulates a person who takes a pregnant woman to a provider cannot be sued if said person is unaware the woman intends to get an abortion. A person could not face multiple lawsuits for one instance of helping a woman get an illegal abortion. Almost any private citizen could file a lawsuit in accordance with SB 1503. Because the law was intentionally written so the state wouldn’t have to enforce it, the state and all political subdivisions are barred from filing lawsuits. As are officers or employees of state or local government entities. The law expressly prohibits someone who impregnated a woman through rape or incest from bringing a lawsuit against their victim. Successful plaintiffs could be awarded at least $10,000 in damages.Could Oklahomans be sued for donating to a fund that helps women seek out an abortion?The law is murky on this point. SB 1503 expressly prohibits “paying for or reimbursing the costs of an abortion through insurance or otherwise.”It’s unclear if that prohibition could apply to an Oklahoman who helps pay for a woman to seek an abortion out of state. It’s also unclear if Oklahomans who donate to entities like the Roe Fund, which provides financial assistance to women seeking abortions, could be subject to a civil lawsuit. In Texas, anti-abortion lawyers are pushing to get information about those who donated to two abortion funds with the aim of suing those individuals for “aiding and abetting” illegal abortions.Someone could bring a lawsuit anytime in the six years following a woman’s illegal abortion. The law is not retroactive, and does not extend to abortions that occurred before the law took effect.What does the abortion law say about determining whether an embryo has a 'fetal heartbeat'?The law says a physician cannot “knowingly perform” an abortion if they detect a “fetal heartbeat,” which is defined in the act as cardiac activity or the steady and repetitive rhythmic contraction of the fetal heart.The law also prevents doctors from performing an abortion without first testing for a “fetal heartbeat.”Oklahoma law requires providers to perform an ultrasound before an abortion. At six weeks, the embryo has not developed chambers of the heart, so it’s inaccurate to call any cardiac activity a “heartbeat.” But an ultrasound machine may translate electronic impulses from cardiac activity in very early pregnancy into sounds that resemble a heartbeat. Does this abortion law apply to Oklahoma residents who travel to other states for the procedure? Looking to Texas’ SB 8, the law after which Oklahoma’s new ban was modeled, the law wouldn’t apply to those who travel out of state to get an abortion where it is legal. Under SB 1503, people can bring lawsuits against those who perform an abortion, or those who “aid or abet” someone in getting an abortion. But the person receiving an abortion couldn’t be sued. Still, it’s murky. Since the law will push enforcement of the ban to civil courts, it’s impossible to rule out that someone won’t try to sue an abortion provider or someone who assists an Oklahoman in accessing an abortion out of state. Ultimately, the courts would have to determine whether such a lawsuit could proceed.Does this law apply to medication abortions?Senate Bill 1503 applies to both procedural and medication abortions after a “fetal heartbeat” is detected. Medication abortions involve taking a series of pills over a few days and can be performed up to 10 weeks into a woman’s pregnancy. A procedural abortion is done in a clinic over a few hours.Access to emergency contraception, sometimes called “Plan B” or the “morning after” pill, isn’t affected by this law. Emergency contraception doesn’t induce an abortion or terminate a pregnancy; the pill works by temporarily delaying ovulation and preventing fertilization. It’s meant to be taken up to three to five days after unprotected sex to prevent pregnancy, but is most effective the sooner you take it. What exceptions to the new abortion law exist? SB 1503 makes an exception allowing doctors to perform abortions later than six weeks in the event of a medical emergency. There is no exception for later abortions in the event of rape or incest.When asked about the "medical emergency" exception in another Oklahoma abortion ban that will go into effect in August — which would make performing an abortion a felony — Stitt said it will be up to doctors to make that call. But this is a gray area, Oklahoma doctors have said. The law doesn’t define what counts as a medical emergency or lay out specific circumstances when an abortion can be performed to protect the mother’s life or health.That could leave doctors vulnerable to legal trouble if someone determined they intervened inappropriately, one Oklahoma OB-GYN said.Under SB1503, physicians would be required to include in a woman’s medical records notes on why they felt an abortion was a medical necessity.Oklahoma law doesn’t allow for medication abortion pills to be prescribed through telehealth visits — a physician has to be physically present to prescribe them.The state also passed two laws in 2021 that would place several restrictions on medication abortions, including prohibiting shipments of the pills directly to Oklahomans by mail. The Oklahoma Supreme Court blocked the implementation of those laws in October by granting a temporary injunction while a legal challenge is ongoing.What resources exist for someone who wants an abortion?Planned Parenthood and Trust Women both operate clinics in Oklahoma that provide abortions allowed under state law. Planned Parenthood also has staff outside of Oklahoma who can help walk a person through their legal abortion options. ineedana.com can help direct people who want an abortion to the clinic nearest to them, based on how far along their pregnancy is and abortion laws in their area. The Miscarriage and Abortion Hotline is staffed by clinicians who give advice on self-managing a miscarriage or abortion. It’s available by phone or text at 833-246-2632.Abortion terms to knowWhen someone is six weeks pregnant, that means six weeks have passed since their last menstrual period. That could mean a person’s period could be about two weeks late, if they have regular monthly periods. Doctors calculate how many weeks pregnant a person is based on when their last period was. That’s a consistent way of dating a pregnancy, according to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG), because it eliminates variability in determining when during the menstrual cycle a person ovulates. Experts use various terms for a developing baby during pregnancy. From eight weeks since a pregnant person’s last menstrual period, it’s called an embryo. From then on, until delivery, it’s called a fetus, according to the ACOG.Legislation to restrict abortions may often refer to a “fetal heartbeat” in determining a cutoff point for access to the procedures, but at the six-week mark, an embryo hasn’t developed chambers of the heart yet, so there is no recognizable “heartbeat” at that point.In very early pregnancy, “what pregnant people may hear is the ultrasound machine translating electronic impulses that signify fetal cardiac activity into sound” we may recognize as a heartbeat, the ACOG explains on its website. Until the chambers of the heart have been developed, typically about 17 to 20 weeks, it’s inaccurate to call an embryo or fetus’ cardiac development a “heartbeat,” according to the ACOG. There are multiple types of abortion procedures. Medication abortions are one kind, and in 2020, they made up about 65% of the 3,797 abortions recorded in Oklahoma. In a medication abortion, a person takes a drug called mifepristone along with another medication called misoprostol about 24-48 hours later to end a pregnancy within about 10 weeks’ gestation or less.Some abortions can also be performed in a clinic. These might sometimes be referred to as “surgical abortions,” but these types of procedures aren’t surgery because they don’t involve an incision.
